Award.AwardTitle: EARS: Novel Beam Steering Apertures and Waveforms for High Capacity Broadband Wireless Nodes

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal Summary - Novel Beam Steering Apertures and Waveforms for High Capacity Broadband Wireless Nodes

Intellectual Merit

The demand for broadband wireless has put existing systems to their limits. In not so distant future mobile Gb/s portable and wearable wireless nodes will be required which will necessitate significant improvements in spectral efficiency. This work proposes an integrated research concept which brings together innovations in beam steering antenna arrays and interference immune waveforms and algorithms. To date most of the antennas and arrays that have been developed for portable and wearable wireless applications have fixed broad beams. This makes them very inefficient because much of the radiated radio frequency power is absorbed by the head or the body resulting in wasted battery power. In this work led by USC significantly smaller form factor antenna arrays will be developed by exploiting the steerable parasitic array concept. The dependency of the array gain and angular coverage on array parameters will be studied to develop new design rules. From a systems perspective, efforts have been devoted to maximize spectral efficiency within heterogeneous networking strategies. However, conventional spectrum utilization strategies which are developed for homogeneous networks are being integrated to the heterogeneous networks, which stand as the bottleneck of the heterogeneous network. To break that bottleneck the concept of enhanced partial overlapping domains is proposed by the USF team. For the first time, beam steering approaches at the mobile will be combined with time-frequency utilization considering enhanced partially overlapped domains. A system level testbed will be developed to evaluate the performance of the proposed arrays and waveforms.

Broader Impacts

The broader impact of this work includes its potential for new fundamental knowledge generation in the field of beam steering antenna arrays and interference immune waveforms/algorithms for future high capacity portable/wearable wireless applications. This will have effects on commercial and military communication domains. Immediate tangible outcome will be a system level testbed that will provide results, outcomes, and design guidelines to prospective designers. This research also involves a team from Benedict College, Columbia, SC, an HBCU (Historically Black Colleges and Universities) Institution. POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to study and develop novel beam steering antennas and communication algorithms for below 6 GHz frequencies. This include next generation cellular, Wi-Fi, LTE (Long Term Evolution) etc. systems. Both handheld and wearable platforms were considered. Existing mobile handheld devices do not contain high performance beam steering antenna arrays. As a demonstrator a smart phone mountable antenna array consisting of driven and parasitic dipoles was designed and developed. The parasitic elements when controlled using PIN diode switches allowed beam steering in three different directions. Theoretical analysis of the beam steering array demonstrated significant performance improvement, such as Carrier to Interference Noise Ratio. Results can be seen in the paper - N.H. Chamok, M.H. Yilmaz, A. Arslan, and M. Ali, “High-Gain Pattern Reconfigurable MIMO Antenna Array for Wireless Handheld Terminals,’’   IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation, pp, 4306-4315, Oct. 2016

For wearable applications a fabric based wearable antenna array was developed that can be integrated into the clothing or uniform of a person, such as first responders. Such an array implemented using conductive and non-conductive fabrics show good gain and beam steering capabilities. Results can be seen in the paper - P. Czeresko, N. Chamok, and M. Ali, “Fabric based beam steering wearable antenna array,’’ 12th European Conference on Antennas and Propagation, April 2018, London, UK. Under the same thrust a narrow-beam beam steerable series-fed antenna array was designed and developed. This array consisting of varactor diodes is simple and low cost because it does not contain traditional phase shifters. The proposed array can steer its beam effectively between -25 to +25 degrees. Results can be seen in the paper - N.H. Chamok, M.N. Alam, and M. Ali, “High-Gain Series-Fed Phased Array Antenna for Wearable Wireless Applications,’’ 12th European Conference on Antennas and Propagation, April 2018, London, UK.

Partially overlapping tones (POT) offer great promise because it decreases the interference on users for uncoordinated networks. Under conventional scenario each user causes interference to other users while utilizing the same resources. With POT this destructive interference can be significantly reduced. A game theoretical partially overlapping filtered multitone scheme was performed in both frequency and space domains. For example, carrier frequency shift was introduced in frequency domain while reconfigurable antennas were utilized in space domain. Within the proposed approach, users while searching for the frequency shift ratio also select an antenna state to increase the system utility. We demonstrated that system level capacity gain improves significantly. Results can be seen in - M.H. Yilmaz, S. Kose, N.H. Chamok, M. Ali, and H. Arslan, “Partially overlapping filtered multitone with reconfigurable antennas in uncoordinated networks,’’ Elsevier Journal of Physical Communication, vol. 25, part 1, pp. 249-258, Dec. 2017.
